content: The "Family Tax Relief Act of 2008" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically expanding the dependent care credit by adding a new section for expenses related to household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The "Family Tax Relief Act of 2008" expands the dependent care credit for individuals with qualifying dependents, allowing a credit against taxes for employment-related expenses paid during the taxable year. The applicable percentage of the credit is determined based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The "Family Tax Relief Act of 2008" expands the dependent care credit for individuals with qualifying dependents, allowing a credit against taxes for employment-related expenses paid during the taxable year. Qualifying individuals include dependents under age 13, those physically or mentally incapable of self-care, and spouses who are incapable of self-care. The "Family Tax Relief Act of 2008" expands the dependent care credit for individuals with qualifying dependents, allowing a credit against taxes for employment-related expenses paid during the taxable year. Qualifying individuals include dependents under age 13, those physically or mentally incapable of self-care, and spouses who are incapable of self-care. The term 'employment-related expenses' refers to amounts paid for household services and care of a qualifying individual to enable the taxpayer to be gainfully employed. The "Family Tax Relief Act of 2008" expands the dependent care credit for individuals with qualifying dependents, allowing a credit against taxes for employment-related expenses paid during the taxable year. Employment-related expenses include amounts paid for household services and care of a qualifying individual to enable the taxpayer to be gainfully employed, such as services provided outside the taxpayer's household at a camp where the qualifying individual stays overnight. Services outside the household must be for the care of a qualifying individual under specific conditions. The dependent care credit under the "Family Tax Relief Act of 2008" applies to services provided outside the taxpayer's household by a dependent care center that complies with state regulations and cares for more than six individuals. The dependent care credit limits the amount of employment-related expenses that can be claimed, with a maximum of $5,000 for one qualifying individual or $10,000 for two or more qualifying individuals. This amount is reduced by any income excluded under section 129. The earned income limitation for employment-related expenses under section 129 for the taxable year is based on the individual's earned income or the earned income of their spouse. There is a special rule for a spouse who is a student or incapable of caring for themselves. For tax purposes, a spouse who is a student or qualifying individual is considered gainfully employed with a minimum income of $250 or $500 per month, depending on the circumstances. Special rules apply regarding the principal place of abode for individuals and taxpayers. Married couples must file a joint return for the taxable year to be eligible for the tax credit. Individuals legally separated under a divorce decree are not considered married for tax purposes. If a qualifying individual maintains a household for more than half the year and covers over half the cost, and their spouse is not part of the household for the last 6 months of the taxable year, they are not considered married for tax purposes. Special rules apply for dependent children under certain circumstances. Payments made to related individuals will not qualify for a tax credit if the individual is eligible for a deduction for personal exemptions as a dependent. The term 'student' refers to an individual who is a full-time student at an educational organization for 5 calendar months during the taxable year. The term 'educational organization' is defined as an educational organization described in section 170(b)(1)(A)(ii). No credit is allowed for any amount paid to a person unless identifying information is provided with respect to the service provider. The credit for qualifying individuals requires providing identifying information for the service provider, including name, address, and taxpayer identification number. Failure to provide this information can be excused if the taxpayer can demonstrate due diligence in attempting to do so. The credit for qualifying individuals requires the taxpayer to include the TIN of the individual on the return claiming the credit. Dollar amounts are adjusted for inflation annually, and regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to implement this section. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by striking references to section 21 and replacing them with section 36. This includes amendments related to filing requirements, marital status, limitation of exclusion, special rules for certain spouses, and dependent care. Conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 replace references to section 21 with section 36 in various sections, including those related to dependent care assistance, exclusion of amounts for certain dependents, and clerical errors. Additionally, the table of sections is amended to reflect this change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by replacing references to section 21 with section 36 in various sections. Additionally, the table of sections is updated to reflect this change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace references to section 21 with section 36. This change applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Additionally, there is an expansion of the teacher expenses deduction. The deduction for certain expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers is amended to allow deductions up to $450 for expenses related to books, supplies, computer equipment, and other equipment. The deduction for certain expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers is amended to allow deductions up to $450 for expenses related to books, supplies, computer equipment, and other equipment used for professional development. The $450 amount will be adjusted for inflation after 2008. The amendment allows for adjustments to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007, with rounding to the nearest multiple of $10 for adjusted amounts. Permanent extension of adoption tax relief under the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, with an exception for amendments related to the expansion of adoption credit and assistance programs.
